entry.et: Middle English, from Old English, weak; akin to Middle Low German lucht left; from the left hand's being the weaker in most individuals

def.dt: :of, relating to, situated on, or being the side of the body in which the heart is mostly located
:done with the left hand a left hook to the jaw
:located nearer to the left hand than to the right
:located on the left of an observer facing in the same direction as the object specified stage left
:located on the left when facing downstream the left bank of a river
:of, adhering to, or constituted by the left especially in politics
:the left hand
:the location or direction of the left side
:the part on the left side
:a turn to the left take a left at the intersection
:left field
:a blow struck with the left fist
:the part of a legislative chamber located to the left of the presiding officer
:the members of a continental European legislative body occupying the left as a result of holding more radical political views than other members

:those professing views usually characterized by desire to reform or overthrow the established order especially in politics and usually advocating change in the name of the greater freedom or well-being of the common man
:a radical as distinguished from a conservative position

entry.et: Middle English leven, from Old English lǣfan; akin to Old High German verleiben to leave, Old English belīfan to be left over, and perhaps to Lithuanian lipti to adhere, Greek lipos grease, fat

def.dt: :bequeath devise left a fortune to his son
:to have remaining after one's death leaves a widow and two children
:to cause to remain as a trace or aftereffect oil leaves a stain the wound left an ugly scar
:to cause or allow to be or remain in a specified condition leave the door open his manner left me cold
:to fail to include or take along left the notes at home the movie leaves a lot out
:to have as a remainder 4 from 7 leaves 3
:to permit to be or remain subject to another's action or control just leave everything to me
:let
:to cause or allow to be or remain available leave room for expansion left myself an out
:to go away from :depart leave the room
:desert abandon left his wife
:to terminate association with :withdraw from left school before graduation
:to put, deposit, or deliver before or in the process of departing I left a package for you leave a message
:set out depart
:to refrain from bothering, disturbing, or using

entry.pt: Leave (sense 2e) with the infinitive but without to leave it be is a mostly spoken idiom used in writing especially for humorous effect. It is not often criticized in British English, but American commentators, adhering to an opinion first expressed in 1881, still dislike it.

entry.et: Middle English leven, from leef leaf

def.dt: :leaf
:of, relating to, situated in, or characteristic of the bohemian district of Paris on the left bank of the Seine River
:the left cerebral hemisphere of the human brain especially when viewed in terms of its predominant thought processes (as analytic and logical thinking)
:the position of the player defending left field
:the part of the baseball outfield to the left looking out from the plate
:a state or position far from the mainstream (as of prevailing opinion) they were really out in left field with that idea
:a source of the unexpected or illogical that question came out of left field
:situated on the left
:left-handed
:using the left hand habitually or more easily than the right
:swinging from left to right a left–handed batter
:relating to, designed for, or done with the left hand
:morganatic
:clumsy awkward
:insincere backhanded dubious a left–handed compliment
:having a direction contrary to that of the hands of a watch viewed from in front :counterclockwise
:having a spiral structure or form that ascends or advances to the left a left–handed rope
:having or being the L-form molecular structure
